entry.title: 13 Going On 31
entry.content:
‚ÄúYou teach me now how cruel¬†you‚Äôve¬†been‚Äîcruel and false. Why did you despise me? Why did you betray your own heart, Cathy? I have not one word of comfort. You deserve this. You have killed yourself. Yes, you may kiss me, and cry; and wring out my kisses and tears:¬†they‚Äôll¬†blight you‚Äîthey‚Äôll¬†damn you. You loved me‚Äîthen what right had you to leave me? What right‚Äîanswer me‚Äîfor the poor fancy you felt for Linton? Because misery and degradation, and death, and nothing that God or Satan could inflict would have parted us, you, of your own will, did it. I have not broken your heart‚Äîyou have broken it; and in breaking it, you have broken mine. So much the worse for me, that I am strong. Do I want to live? What kind of living will it be when you‚Äîoh, God! would you like to live with your soul in the grave?‚Äù

Emily Bront√´, ‚ÄúWuthering Heights‚Äù

I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm writing this! Let alone writing, period. It‚Äôs been a full year since my last post, where I celebrated turning thirty in my favorite place in the world. Today, I am back in Hokkaido.
My website perished over the past year due to budget constraints, but now a new and improved version is slowly coming together.
Just like me. I was so alive between 27-30 years old. Now, my life feels dead again.
How did I get here? Why does my 31 self mirror me at 13? And what have I learned?
Last year, I drew thirty conclusions. Now, I am not so sure. I already know my strengths and weaknesses. I know my potential and worth. I know what I can offer, and what needs work.
Having neglected writing in the past year, I feel compelled to trace it first, and then see how I‚Äôve matured.

My Life at 30

February 2025

  • Trying to prevent my first suffocating relationship. This new guy showers me with care, and breaks the cycle of ghosting in my (unrequited) love life. But demands constant attention, monitors me to ensure that ‚Äúno one steals‚Äù me, and blames me for turning him mad
  • He suggests celebrating my birthday as friends, shows up with a cake and presents, pressures me to act like a couple, and says he wants to settle down. On VALENTINE‚ÄôS DAY
  • My best birthday, and one of my happiest days, one year ago in snowy Hokkaido, at my favorite ryokan, with my favorite hot spring and tour guide; seeing penguins and savoring my favorite sushi chain
  • Meeting another grandma from Hokkaido who takes me under her wing (February 2026 update: she sends me presents every few months, I feel so unworthy)
  • A Japanese aunt who exploited and stalked me in 2023 texting: ‚ÄúHappy birthday! Where are you?‚Äù
  • Teaching myself music production, creating songs almost daily, and resenting my friends for ignoring my passions
  • Returning to Japanese language school and realizing that my recent conclusion - ‚Äúpeople won‚Äôt make time for me even if they want to because I‚Äôm not special enough‚Äù - is false. The classmate I‚Äôd been trying to befriend isn‚Äôt too busy for others
  • Studying business Japanese and trying to socialize with other classmates, who pick phones over friendship. A creepy Israeli student from another class comes to mine every day during recess and breaking up my conversations with my classmates
  • Giving the love bomber another chance and resisting his gaslighting until we break up
  • Wondering why guys I dated in Taiwan still text me and whether I should have moved to Taipei
  • Winning a prize at the school‚Äôs kanji contest
  • Deciding that I finally want monogamy

March 2025

  • Dating a famous guy who treats me to fancy places, showers me with presents, and offers to fly me to his residences. Not my first time, but still baffling, since I am used to ghosting, and feel unworthy
  • Winning an award at a Japanese speech contest in front of a few hundred people and industry officials, but failing to Á©∫Ê∞ó„ÇíË™≠„ÇÄ
  • Fainting at a clinic after the nurse can‚Äôt draw my blood
  • My chest tightening every day because the person I‚Äôm in love with doesn‚Äôt know I exist
  • Struggling to find this spark by dating locals
  • Making it up to the love bomber on his birthday, exchanging sincere apologies, and achieving my first romantic closure
  • Realizing that my relationships are asymmetrical
  • Understanding that friendship and romance work differently in East Asia. The former is distant, while the latter is stifling. Many Asians seem to learn deep connection through Westerners, and then love bomb so as to not lose their chance to be open about their true self
  • Turning into Charlotte from Sex and the City. ‚ÄúNever sleep with someone you like on the first date.‚Äù I start taking it slow, and eschew meaningless hookups. I‚Äôm still a Samantha - until romance is involved. (In retrospect, no one I date ghosts me from now on)
  • Spending a magical week with a tourist whose country I am banned from. The only time in my life where I feel like a teenager experiencing his first romance. There is mutual love (finally!) and, even though I don‚Äôt believe in fate, signs. It‚Äôs the beginning of spring, and he‚Äôs never seen snow; the forecast predicts warm sun, when thick snow blankets Tokyo
  • Bidding him farewell on the way to my first shift at a place that traumatized my adolescence - a synagogue. Wiping my cheeks and putting on a face at work
  • Food poisoning from the synagogue making me so sick for a week, that I almost need an ambulance. While devastated that the tourist is gone
  • Finding myself in yet another long-distance situationship

April 2025

  • Relishing my first cherry blossoms in Tokyo, but feeling lonely since my loved ones live abroad
  • A Taiwanese uncle twice my age arriving in Tokyo with a present for me: a duck figurine, slang for male prostitute. He showed me around Taiwan two years ago, and now comes to Tokyo to meet a ‚Äúwoman pen pal‚Äù he has feelings for
  • Plucking up the courage to do something that requires a lot of confidence, only to experience my worst night of clubbing, and one of my most degrading experiences. I feel ugly, and cry myself to sleep
  • Starting the last term in my beloved school on the next day, appreciating life as a student, and growing tired of the anti-social vibe in class
  • Starting to chase things that scare me. If I don‚Äôt put myself out there, I will stagnate and merely exist
  • Meeting a tourist from Europe who feels like the read deal from the first moment. Wise and goofy, mature and young, Eastern and Western, passionate and Zen
  • Cursing distance for curtailing my best romantic and platonic connections
  • Finding that my EU passport application is successful in proving my eligibility, yet a new language law will ruin it

May 2025

  • A rocky Golden Week, in which I perform an original song live for the first time; finally enjoy clubbing as much as my first time two years ago, when a toxic ex resurfaces to ask for tips on hooking up with Israelis (exactly one month before my pathetic plan to make it up for him on his birthday); arguing over his manipulations for hours until dawn, until he calls me a ‚Äúfictional character‚Äù who makes everything up; losing the part of me that believes in romance; and, a day later, meeting a new guy (who, in hindsight, becomes my most stable, respectful, and consistent relationship)
  • Realizing my parents and exes tend to gaslight, and re-having my ongoing nightmares from middle school
  • Understanding the meaning of ‚Äúbad romance‚Äù. I crave someone who hurts me and claims we‚Äôre just friends. I‚Äôm ‚Äúon my own, kid‚Äù, but ‚ÄúI can do it with a broken heart‚Äù, and ‚ÄúI can fix him‚Äù. (Then, discovering that people don‚Äôt want to be fixed)
  • Realizing that my life can be summed up in two words: feeling invisible. The first guy I dated seriously was the first to see me. He promised to be there for me, then hit block
  • Breaking into tears over all this‚Ä¶ while having sex
  • My psoriasis coming back instead of people
  • Finding a cure in songwriting (and steroids), shooting a music video
  • Attending Tokyo‚Äôs most famous festivals, which pale in comparison to the countryside
  • Falling out of love with people who show me their true face
  • A Taiwanese guy I dated a year ago randomly texting me ‚ÄúI love you, I will come visit you‚Äù
  • The Japanese grandma complaining when I don‚Äôt reply to her constant messages. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre like family,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúand meeting you was a once-in-a-lifetime encounter‚Äù
  • Job hunting to prevent my return to Israel, where I have to hide my true self and live a lie (this already happened in 2020 after school in England)
  • Having my first panic attack in three years. My visa is about to expire, my money is about to run out, and I dedicate every day to making songs that all of my friends ignore. Everything I do is a failure
  • Betraying my values and agreeing to full-time work at the synagogue
  • Meditating at night for two weeks, embracing pain, and stabilizing my mental state

June 2025

  • Dating Tokyo locals. It‚Äôs slow and steady, but the chemistry is low
  • Wondering if requited love can be as grand as unrequited
  • Heating up with the Golden Week guy, who calls me every day now, opens up about his secrets, and communicates candidly to ensure I don‚Äôt get hurt
  • Dreading another ghosting, and realizing that liars have turned me suspicious
  • One week with five exams at school, the government‚Äôs notorious Business Japanese Test, a part time job, performing live again, a Japanese work visa application, a European passport application, and volunteering at a disappointingly tame Tokyo Pride, where I see the blocking ex and club with shy locals
  • Negotiating a contract rife with absurd clauses copy-pasted by a clueless immigration lawyer, since my boss neither read it nor wrote a word
  • Discovering that Japanese people can be distant and artificially polite to everyone, not just Westerners, out of fear of being a burden. Lamenting this cultural pressure to be quiet, and wishing to support them
  • Graduating! RIP my student era
  • NOT getting paid because my boss neglects my salary, then asks me to break the visa law
  • ‚ÄúMy heart aches for you,‚Äù says the GW guy, ‚ÄúI want to take care of you.‚Äù Turns out he also fears me ghosting him
  • Finding myself in yet another long-distance situationship
  • Mourning my impossible romances and friends who are gone

July 2025

  • One week where I take the JLPT N2, apply for a work visa while my boss ignores my request for documents required by the immigration office, and pack for a last-minute silent retreat
  • Worrying about my future, feeling unseen by my friends, and taking a break from social media. I fret about hurting the tourists with my absence, even though we‚Äôre just platonic at this point, but they aren‚Äôt there for me
  • Saying goodbye to the classmate I like the most. Turns out she also wanted to make friends and disliked the anti-social vibe at school. Sad we didn‚Äôt hang out more
  • Meditating from dawn to night while sitting still for almost two weeks at a Buddhist centre in the countryside, where talking, making eye contact, using technology, exercising, reading, and writing is forbidden. I do the latter on my first day, agonize over my disobedience, confess, almost get expelled, and abide by the rules; suffer constant pain and cramps, disagree with the brainwashing lectures, and starve from two meals per day; enjoy the digital detox and clean air, rewrite an old story, compose five songs, and draft three albums; recall why art is my ride or die, followed by health and the people I love; count the hours to freedom, but then appreciate this experience so much, that I almost extend my stay
  • Second time where I go on a digital detox in Japan and check out with a local guy I feel tension with. Last time I was too shy to ask for his number, but this time I wait at the train station, and we hang out
  • Returning to life in the world‚Äôs busiest hub feeling cleansed and peaceful; missing neither drama, nor humans; eager to write - only to drop my electronics into the bath
  • Not knowing who I am anymore: an introverted writer who doesn‚Äôt need people, or an extroverted adventurer who aches for love
  • Reuniting with a guy I dated two years ago in Korea. Neither of us thought we‚Äôd meet again
  • Sweating every day while dying of boredom, because I can afford neither a computer nor a trip on my last days of freedom before work
  • Fancying stand-up comedy and preparing jokes
  • ‚ÄúYou changed me and gave me hope,‚Äù says GW. I can help people, after all? We admit our feelings, but agree to just be friends

August 2025

  • The beginning of my worst period since 2022. With eleven hours of my weekdays going to work, commuting one hour each way on the world‚Äôs busiest train line to a company where I earn little to juggle its operations by myself as the sole employee in the office, and most of my leisure spent on planning my family‚Äôs fall visit, my social life is over
  • Trying to take initiative at work by optimizing operations, addressing customer complaints, clarifying bewildering practices, and reducing costs, until my boss shuts it down to ‚Äúdouble my workload‚Äù (direct quote)
  • Discovering that my contract omitted ‚Äúbecome the personal assistant of a family that doesn‚Äôt speak Japanese‚Äù
  • Agonizing over hurting people with my ongoing disappearance, while feeling too drained to return to social media
  • The creepy Israeli student cancelling his best friend (another Israeli student) because he can‚Äôt stand it when people (like me) have other friends and not give him undivided attention. He jokes that he and I should go on dates (he told me he‚Äôs aroace), shows up unannounced at my doorstep, and forces me to go to dinner with him
  • Spending my lunch breaks with the only guy who seems to value me (GW)
  • Doing stand-up comedy at a bar. The audience laughs!
  • Passing the JLPT with a high score!
  • Entering a Western portal in a Japanese beach town where people show skin, play music, and socialize. A wacky Japanese grandpa, married to an Israeli woman, calls me Kesennuma-kun and Gaza ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs skinniest country‚Äù (thereby dethroning Japan)

September 2025

  • FINALLY GETTING PAID AND BUYING A COMPUTER
  • No longer agonizing over unrequited love. I finally have someone who loves me and is there for me
  • Re-planning my family‚Äôs newly-extended visit, because my boss rejected my vacation
  • Every person who hears about this job tells me to quit, report him to the media, and escape to Israel. But I live in my favorite neighborhood of my favorite city in my favorite country, where I am free to be myself, and in my private time, to do as I want
  • Trying crowd work at the comedy bar
  • Incorporating more protein into my diet and finally gaining weight
  • The love bomber messaging me as if we‚Äôre dating again
  • Celebrating my first day off by visiting the bank and post office, since my job bars me from running errands (finally, a Japanese debit card!)
  • Surprising my family at Narita airport and embarking on an intense three-week trip in Japan, while working half of the time at the office

October 2025

  • Fighting with my mom every day on the trip because she wrinkles her nose incessantly and screams at me for creating a bad itinerary, which she never deigned to glance at in the six months it took me to plan it
  • Getting along with my sister, enjoying Japan and our precious time together
  • Agonizing because I love my mom but feel mistreated by her for a decade
  • Re-visiting favorite places in Japan for the first time in 2.5 years and taking bullet trains across the country to make it to the office and then meet my family again in Kansai. I have no moment to myself
  • Finishing the trip physically and emotionally exhausted, limping from back pain for two weeks because of physical labor outside my job description, and consulting my school for legal advice
  • Asking my boss to work four days a week due to health reasons resulting from said work, only to be fired on the spot
  • Confronting a close friend about her lack of support, only to enter a series of long fights late on work nights, and be blamed for her behavior
  • The second annual Friends Visit Tokyo Between October to January For Some Reason, Stay in My One-Bedroom Apartment, and Expect to Hang Out All Day Long begins with three months of friends suddenly acting like we‚Äôre besties because we temporarily reside in the same city. I genuinely have fun with them, but it drains my meagre energy and resources
  • Wearing a summery Halloween costume to a down-pouring, heavily-policed Shibuya

November 2025

  • Freezing every day from now on as a Middle Easterner in a climate that is actually cold
  • My boss monitoring me out of spite more than any predecessor (and I‚Äôve never had a boss who didn‚Äôt micromanage, swindle, and exploit)
  • My mom monitoring, screaming, controlling, and guilt-tripping me from Israel, to the point where I nearly cut ties with her at 30 years old (having done this with my dad at 15 years old), only to be contacted by the Jewish community in Tokyo asking if I‚Äôm ALIVE because I screened her angry phone calls for a few hours. She nearly contacted the embassy and police (the latter already happened in 2022)
  • Helping the close friend who fought me in October with her crisis. She cries that no one has supported her like this, and apologizes
  • The creepy Israeli continuing to message me just to vent about his best friend
  • Finding out I‚Äôm fired even though we agreed on four-day workweeks. I lose my income, my visa security, and my remaining energy. I can‚Äôt even talk

December 2025

  • Free from hell, but at what cost?
  • Reuniting with the close friend who is now visiting again, happy we‚Äôve resolved our problems
  • Sightseeing Tokyo to get some forest therapy via fall colors
  • Being pressured into an impromptu trip to Israel because my dad suddenly won the president‚Äôs award. It‚Äôs been a year since my last visit, and every week someone tells me to come home. I am torn between using this rare opportunity of not losing money and vacation days on an undesired trip, and dreading more arguments
  • Reuniting with GW on a weekend full of romantic tension. ‚ÄúIs this a mistake?‚Äù he cries during sex. ‚ÄúShould I move to Tokyo, or you to my city?‚Äù But we want different things, and agree to just be friends
  • Realizing I suffer from Tourist Syndrome, where the highlights of my platonic and romantic life are far and ephemeral
  • Chasing my boss for termination documents and being ghosted; discovering he has never insured me, and just took my money; booking a last-minute flight to Israel; rushing to unemployment agencies and the immigration office; sending documents to my workplace via express delivery with detailed instructions
  • Reuniting with friends and family, surprising my mom, savoring my favorite food, meeting the prime minister and president in Jerusalem, and actually having a good time in Israel (I‚Äôm still shocked)
  • Running into a Thai-Israeli girl I met three years ago in Korea. In ABU DHABI
  • Celebrating Christmas in Japan with the close friend
  • Returning to social media after six months, only to find that people I miss a lot didn‚Äôt notice I was gone
  • Suffering my worst sleep problems since 2022 due to jet lag and insomnia (I used to be treated at a sleep clinic and achieved progress, but now my life is upside down again)

January 2026

  • More unemployment agencies, since my boss lied and didn‚Äôt do his work!
  • Trying to find a job and not being a failure!
  • Back to rotting in bed without financial security, budget for my social life and passions, motivation, visa security, certainty about my future, success, stable support, and recollection of being in love. As if I‚Äôm a grad student again, quarantining alone in the UK while writing all day long (but hey, I finished some short stories)
  • The final nail in the coffin being the death of my blog. (Money problems) I wrote 2,500 pages of content every day for over a year, but what was I expecting, anyone to notice?
  • Deciding not to date until my life is stable and my issues are solved
  • Not being in love with anyone for the first time in three years. I‚Äôm finally free
  • Reading, watching movies, and playing video games for the first time in three years. In ‚ÄúChildren of Emotionally Immature Parents‚Äù, a clinical psychologist describes my parents and exes word-for-word, explains red and green flags in people, and, to my surprise, recommends tactics I‚Äôve been criticized for since high school: trying to help people; and growing apart when they refuse to grow
  • Overhauling decade-old projects and scrapping others, because it‚Äôs time to admit that some of my stories don‚Äôt work
  • Stabilizing my sleep
  • Finding a better community of young and friendly Israelis in Tokyo than the old, crooked synagogue
  • Attending Lady Gaga‚Äôs concert with another visiting friend. It‚Äôs not just my first concert like this and my biggest idol, who I‚Äôve loved since her debut album. I see myself in her on stage, and recall how I performed for years in childhood. The next day, I can‚Äôt eat from all the inspiration
  • Living and breathing music for a week, where I write ten songs day and night in bed. I go in a new direction creatively, until my head explodes with ideas, and I finally go for a walk
  • Getting compliments for my music for the first time‚Ä¶ from strangers

February 2026

  • Enjoying a snowy weekend in Tokyo. Until my pipe burst and washing machine broke
  • The creepy Israeli student hosting his former best friend at his apartment, pretending that they‚Äôre on good terms, blocking her when she returns to Israel, then showing up unannounced on my doorstep with a present because ‚Äúwe should hang out every day‚Äù
  • Struggling to find a job, worrying about money and visa
  • Preparing my new website, sorting my life story and thoughts
  • Growing tired of people who complain endlessly without taking action to solve their problems, live a lie instead of being themselves, and choose the easy way. I know how they feel and how hard it is to overcome this, but I managed to do so - why can‚Äôt they?
  • Re-reading my 2025 journal with shock. I cried over people? I was in love? Why do things keep happening to me? Am I too trusting - or plain insufferable?
  • Another rocky Valentine‚Äôs Day, in which the Taiwanese uncle confesses his love for me; I realize I enable clingy people by acting nice, and block him, the lover bomber, and Israeli student; perform stand-up comedy and new songs at a queer party with improved confidence and success; sleep two hours; then fly to Hokkaido
  • Deciding to find a balance between my mental serenity after the silent retreat, and my tendency to follow the heat of the moment. Maybe it‚Äôs good none of my long-distance romances worked. It‚Äôs definitely bad when people pressure me with presents and extreme attention

My Life at 13

As a child, I dabbled in a lot of arts.
I mailed the most famous children‚Äôs author in Israel books with fan-fiction that I wrote.
I created a theatre show that I performed every year from kindergarten to middle school.
I played the piano for six years.
I was in the school choir, and opened the graduation show with a solo.
I painted every week and created costumes.
Until middle school, when I was bullied and alone. I quit my hobbies, studied Japanese, and hid my thoughts and emotions. On my 14th birthday, I journaled about my growth.
(The following is a translation of my diary in Hebrew - I will upload pictures of it soon)

16 February 2009

I‚Äôm not excited at all, I just feel like it‚Äôs another normal day. Always, every year, I remember waking up with a smile on my face [‚Ä¶] a million kids bullied me and called me gay, made impressions of me and cussed at me. I‚Äôm used to these things but the weird thing is that today it happened more than ever!

Here I mention a new Pokemon game I‚Äôd wanted for three years. In January 2026, I finally got Pokemon Scarlet, which I‚Äôd wanted for three years.

I‚Äôll probably go out with B and A to a charity event, which sounds fun but kind of screws up my plan to come out in front of them. I think the timing is good and the opportunity as well and we‚Äôll probably be alone (mom at home? Need to check) and the most important thing is that I feel ready, and I‚Äôve been planning this for two weeks now. I really hope it will work out because it will finally help me a lot and reduce a bit of all my stress [‚Ä¶]

I have messed-up genes and I hate my body and my appearance, and I am under so much stress that I don‚Äôt know what to do. I used to cry a lot and this year I cried only once. It began as usual when I told myself I wouldn‚Äôt cry anymore, but now I‚Äôm incapable of doing it. I think it‚Äôs because even though I‚Äôve kept all the wounds inside, and it really made things hard for me and for years I‚Äôve felt so emotional and sensitive and now I don‚Äôt feel that at all. I expect myself to cry now as I‚Äôm writing this, but‚Ä¶ nothing.

I think it‚Äôs because somehow, with time, everything healed. The bullying only became worse but I just became stronger‚Ä¶ and a lot more. It doesn‚Äôt get to me at all anymore, those words don‚Äôt bug me at all at all, and all the wounds, the grudge and the anger that have accumulated inside me all these years are gone. I became stronger and I‚Äôm happy for that partially. I, while writing all this, realised I‚Äôd simply developed a bulletproof shield for myself, one super strong [‚Ä¶]

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs good ‚Äì I mean, it‚Äôs good that I‚Äôve grown up, that it doesn‚Äôt get to me anymore all those things and that I‚Äôm better than that. The fact that I‚Äôve learned to ignore and not get hurt fills me with joy, because I know at least until the end of the school year the bullying will continue and right now it‚Äôs on the rise even though apart from today the entire year went well in that sense. But on the other hand I‚Äôm so bulletproof by now, and the ‚Äúwall‚Äù I‚Äôve developed for myself is so strong and extreme that no one has the ability to go through it. No one, and I barely share people with my secrets.

It‚Äôs very hard for me to open up, and I‚Äôm really scared of how people might react. There are so many who hate my kind of people, and especially you can see it in school. But I know it‚Äôs part of the routine, and it will always exist: not just homophobia, but the kids in class. They‚Äôre just confused and especially during puberty it‚Äôs hard for them to run into people like that, to understand them and know how to react. So I‚Äôm not fazed by this at all and it doesn‚Äôt get to me a-t a-l-l. Anyway I‚Äôd like ‚Äì s-o badly, my emotional stress is so high even though lately it‚Äôs barely felt. I‚Äôm very confused about this situation, and I‚Äôd like to find out about this transformation within me ‚Äì I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs connected to my sexuality ‚Äì it also really interests me, and of course I want to understand what happened, how it affects me. Right now I understand all the stress I‚Äôve always felt is gone; I‚Äôve always felt so hurt, so sensitive‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not only that this, and nothing else right now, bothers me, but that I‚Äôm not even crying. I think it stems from me maturing emotionally in a very extreme way, but also because I‚Äôve just completely shut myself. I‚Äôm not open at all.

And the thing is I‚Äôm d=y=i=n=g for a hug, for touch, for warmth and love, and a boyfriend. I feel really desperate, I‚Äôm ready for a boyfriend but I understand it‚Äôs really really not simple. It will happen with time‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm sure. :P

And now it‚Äôs all coming back to me. Just as I‚Äôm writing all this. I‚Äôm also beginning to formulate a certain theory about my behaviour. I also think after what happened this year: my heart-to-heart conversations with H, and her decision to cut ties with me, really hurt me even though I know it was entirely my fault. I know I hurt her, a lot, and she even told me it was irreparable damage. And she asked me to cut ties. And it made me sad as hell because I really love her [platonically] and it‚Äôs important for me to stay on good terms with her. I understood her and therefore did as she asked. But I was sad.

It also hurt my relationship with B. And suddenly we began to talk, and she also told me the situation didn‚Äôt make her happy. And now I‚Äôm happy like I don‚Äôt know what‚Ä¶ the relationship has gotten so great. We‚Äôre closer than ever. I‚Äôm in the best relationship with the girls, all of them [‚Ä¶]

Anyway, things are completely fixed. And the thing is I think because I felt so relieved due to the good relationships now, and so happy with the situation, that I just didn‚Äôt address my serious problems because I was so happy and thrilled. I guess I just pushed them aside. They‚Äôre probably buried, deep deep inside me, and starting to erupt right now, as I‚Äôm writing, and remembering it all [‚Ä¶]

I planned to come out of the closet in front of them [B and A] but I was counting on an empty house, and it ruined my plan. I escorted them out and when we said goodbye I thought about telling them, but I thought it‚Äôd be too forced, irrelevant and the location was bad. So I gave up.

I do feel ready, very, and I now begin to feel again the great need in emotional discharge, but I realised it won‚Äôt happen. I do want it to be at the ‚Äúright time‚Äù ‚Äì I don‚Äôt just wait and wait for nothing, because I know there‚Äôs no such thing and that you need to initiate on your own. But today I realised it won‚Äôt happen. I wanted to take advantage of this special day, but I felt it was forced, urgent and just inappropriate. Today was too cramped and I didn‚Äôt get enough privacy ‚Äì only now I finally have some time to breathe, and barely too. I haven‚Äôt eaten dinner yet (21:00), and I also need to finish the manga that Ziv from Japanese lent me and return it to him tomorrow because I‚Äôve had it for a month already. And I‚Äôm really tired, I‚Äôm falling asleep as I‚Äôm writing this. But it‚Äôs important for me to write all this. I guess the real recreation on my birthday is mental and emotional discharge to my diary, writing and organizing my thoughts and emotions, which I think is a very important thing, especially in my predicament and need.

Besides I‚Äôm not excited at all on this day, and I thought about it and I think it‚Äôs not for nothing: everything is connected to everything, and even in this matter. When I shut myself down emotionally over the last few months I grew up A LOT. A LOT. So, while all these last years I was just radiant, over the moon ‚Äì I couldn‚Äôt take the smile off my face on my birthdays ‚Äì this year I‚Äôm not. And it also shows my maturation. Not the physical one, which unfortunately came many years too soon, but emotional maturation. And I‚Äôm happy for that and thrilled, and very proud of myself, and I think it was the best present I could‚Äôve asked for my birthday. I finish this diary, which I love so so much, with my favourite characters and series ‚Äì Happy Potter, which will forever be a part of my life ‚Äì with official maturation, wisdom, deep knowledge, and most importantly a lot of order within me. All this writing made me organise my thoughts and understand things better, and I‚Äôm sorry I didn‚Äôt write all this time in the diary because I‚Äôm SURE! it would‚Äôve helped me a long time ago, and I could‚Äôve saved myself great sorrow, but the important thing is that it‚Äôs here! I plan in the very near future to tell B, I don‚Äôt know who else right now, about me being gay, and even more about myself that is no less important. I will start with a journey to find my self, and of course a new diary! So, to be continued. üòä

My Life at 31

Everything about my existence is summed up in the above diary entry. I‚Äôve always felt like an outsider, a stranger to my species; an alien in a world of monsters.
It‚Äôs taken me years to emerge from my spacesuit. At 30, I was finally on stage again. I‚Äôd focused on writing for fifteen years, but by 31, found myself exploring multiple mediums: prose, poetry, music, and comedy.
Since last winter, I wrote fifty songs, and progressed from basic, off-key piano notes to multilayered productions. I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing, and none of it sounds professional - but isn‚Äôt that part of the road?

16 February 2026

Like I wrote one year ago, there are so many things I wish to pursue, but cannot. I am confident in my abilities and vision, yet even the people closest to me dismiss my writing as poor.
Humans can thrive together. The idea that there is a limited number of success in the world is capitalist to a fault.
Arrogance is loving yourself more than others.
Insecurity is loving yourself less than others.
Confidence is loving yourself and others.
Delusion is loving yourself despite not knowing who you are. You deny your weaknesses, and repress your actions. It is so freeing to encounter someone authentically their own: so you shower them with love, to prevent abandonment; and hatred, when they don‚Äôt feed your ego.
This is okay.
Things happen. Everything is forgivable, as long as you admit fault and change course.
Which is why there is nothing more detrimental than someone who never apologizes.
None of us identify as a monster. Most of our offenses are unconscious. As a child, I pestered my classmates in a desperate attempt to have friends, only to end up in middle school alone. This pushed me to become considerate and thoughtful.
Now, I am better. I take criticism, make sacrifices, and weather storms. But I am still sensitive to people who are callous.
I shudder to think that I also hurt others.
Perhaps I make mistakes as much as the next person. But at least I try to correct them. When you call out abuse and the perpetrator denies, projects, and distorts - well, they don‚Äôt care about inflicting pain anymore.
And I will never, ever, EVER! understand that. Family, friends, employers, exes: how can I make them see others - and themselves?
Humans can be humane. They simply don‚Äôt want to. I can‚Äôt change someone who doesn‚Äôt want to change; the only solution is to let go.
I‚Äôm not adept at this. But I think that one mustn‚Äôt excel at letting go. If you really care about something, it will always be in your thoughts.
It‚Äôs such a bitter blow, learning that someone already let go.
I still dream about people I love. I still have nightmares about people I loathe.
As for those I love AND loathe‚Ä¶
Once they show you their true colors, you‚Äôre stuck with what they do, while recalling what they can do.
I would stay off social media, which exacerbates this tension, but artists must build a platform in today‚Äôs digital world.
Messaging can be so distant, compared to hearing someone‚Äôs voice.
Alienation permeates the world. But enough complaining about it nonstop. I want to be fun and funny; I will never be as young as I am in any given moment.
And I‚Äôm grateful for the callous people. They taught me what mistakes to avoid. Now, it‚Äôs up to me to discover what else is out there, through mistakes of my own.
I am young at heart, and my body feels strong. I‚Äôm so lucky to be alive and intact. Age is just a number, so take nudes and leaps of faith. Text your crush!
At various points in my life, I‚Äôve lost lovers and friends, all my money, health, sanity, support, success, possessions, reputation, confidence, appearance, dreams, and joy. So I don‚Äôt have anything to lose anymore.
Apart from hope.
Nine years ago, I wrote thesis after thesis in university about how art can save us. Even when I create to a void, I feel it healing my soul.
And I know, just KNOW, that I have what it takes to spread the cure. There‚Äôs nothing I want to do more than to show people that hope isn‚Äôt dangerous. Life can be wonderful! A wild ride, full of highs and lows. We can be ourselves and find happiness, if we just SEE each other.
It‚Äôs so inspiring, living in a cruel world.

entry.title: Thirty Thoughts for Turning Thirty
entry.content:
‚ÄúWe grow neither better nor worse as we get old, but more like ourselves.‚Äù

May Lamberton Becker

When I was in middle school, I used to joke that I‚Äôd rather die than make it to thirty.

I wasn‚Äôt really joking. Yet here I am.

Specifically, in the highest ryokan in Hokkaido, where I celebrated my best birthday two years ago. My favorite prefecture in Japan, on my favorite season, featuring my favorite onsen, favorite food, favorite hiking guide, and memories of that surprise TV interview: it felt apt to recreate these now, and achieve closure.

Over the past two years, I went through more experiences than in the previous twenty-eight years combined. Discoveries, adventures, love, pain, life-threatening terrors; screaming in freedom, and crying myself to sleep; feeling alive for the first time, and wanting to die. I‚Äôm a different person now.

There are many things I wish to say about those fourteen months of travelling in East Asia, three months of rest in Israel, and seven months of studying in Tokyo. But I can‚Äôt just write them all down. I have too many pursuits, and not enough free time. Adulthood sucks.

So instead, my new blog, Sex and the Biggest City, has become my way of making sense of this period. I will continue to write new chapters, until the story can be published as a memoir.

To my surprise, school has also prompted me to reflect on my past. In the last few weeks, I had to write a user manual about myself in third person; and create a chart about my happiness throughout my life.

As I look back on thirty years of existence, I look forward to a new decade, where things will continue, for better or worse, to surprise me.

For now, the following meditations from the past seven months will encapsulate these.

  1. I used to think that people will make time for me if they want me in their life. Now I know they won‚Äôt make time for me even if they enjoy my company. I am not special enough.

  2. I crave stability, yet reject stagnation. My goal in life is to never sink into a comfort zone and unchanging conditions. I will always seek ways to challenge myself, even at the risk of losing my social, romantic, and mental well-being. Which happened when most aspects of my life - family, friends, romance, money, work, health - deteriorated throughout October, until hitting a new low in December. At least school is okay.

  3. I love being new to things. The downside is making mistakes out of inexperience. The upside is learning from them and improving my psyche.

  4. My mission to experience everything the world has to offer is a direct result of my writer‚Äôs mindset. I seek pain as much as pleasure, because it exposes me to the full array of the human condition. I will say yes to almost anything.

  5. I avoid boredom like fire. Never make small talk with me or expect me to give up my passions for safe monotony.

  6. I can tell if I will get along with someone from the first moment. It all comes down to the spark in their eye. I know who I want to befriend or date before they even open their mouth. Some people seem so dead-eyed, abnormally normal, empty on the inside. Bollas‚Äôs normotic illness is the pernicious epidemic of the postmodern age. Every person I‚Äôve ever loved, whether platonically or romantically, was love at first sight.

  7. My inability to read some people will never cease to frustrate me. I can see things from another person‚Äôs perspective, thereby understanding their thoughts and emotions. Yet some people throw me off so much, that I feel like a failure, both as a human being and a writer. How am I to create diverse characters, or stay on good terms with people who act without emotion or reason?

  8. I recently discovered that I have a type, much to my surprise. Sadly, it is the rarest combination of body and spirit. I can‚Äôt say it to just about anyone, because it will affect their attitude, until they lose precisely the quality that I like.

  9. It is easier for me to make friends as an adult than it was as a child. Most people might attest to the opposite. Thus, I still struggle to make real friends. After trying to do so in Tokyo for seven months, I can‚Äôt say that I have a single close friend here. My best friends for life disappeared for no reason, while my new classmates repeatedly turned me down.

  10. It is not hard to stay in touch. My generation simply lacks the social aplomb to call or message. I don‚Äôt know why a quick ‚Äúhow are you?‚Äù is expecting too much. If you ask about my well-being, I will cherish you for life.

  11. Humans are born with the ability to lead a caring lifestyle. Our biology does not gravitate toward indifference, estrangment, and antagonism. On the contrary, the brain is designed to seek patterns, build connections, and empathize. Society simply corrupts us into playing games with each other, ignoring other people‚Äôs feelings, and trampling peers in imaginary contests. A species whose survival depends on empathy has lost interest in mere sympathy. Thus, Hegel‚Äôs master-slave dialectics are a result of Althusser‚Äôs interpellation.

  12. I despise human beings with all my might. Yet without their recognition, I would lose my mind. I will never stop believing in their potential to do good. Ergo, I will always end up disappointed by their misconduct.

  13. Love and traveling make me feel alive. Yet I would give them up in an instant to publish my stories and make a living as an author. Writing will always be number one.Would I still be happy in this scenario, though, as a successful, albeit lonely, writer? I honestly can‚Äôt tell. But I will never be happy as a failed writer who has friends.

  14. Nothing on this planet scares me anymore, and there‚Äôs nothing I can‚Äôt do, as long as it is only up to me. I can live alone on the other side of the globe and travel by myself to countries I know nothing about. I can dance alone in nightclubs and hit on people out of my league. I can control my anxiety and act despite my qualms. I can take criticism, combat any problem, and implement any desire. Every skill necessary for self-sufficiency and survival, I have acquired. My only obstacles are money, and other people‚Äôs apathy.

  15. There is no correlation between maturity and success. Many people I know in high-ranking or well-paying positions are emotionally crippled, too lazy or anxious to perform simple tasks, lack basic communication skills, can‚Äôt maintain a household or spend time alone, are intimidated by planning and preparation, and only do as they please, instead of meeting people halfway.

  16. The key to dealing with mixed signals is to disregard words and only pay attention to actions. I never say something I don‚Äôt mean, and consider words sacred, so it took me this long to understand that many people contradict this. If their actions speak different, there is no point in holding on to lies masquerading as promises.

  17. I am alone in the world, whether I live in my birth country or on the other side of the planet. Because I‚Äôm the black sheep of my family - the only one with a different personality, worldview, and passions, who wants to stop arguing. They will never solve their problems, let alone admit them, and instead continue fighting over the same things for decades. They watch each other like hawks and shove their noses to every affair; criticize and scream about things they pretended not to mind; make promises or denunciations they don‚Äôt mean; deny shouting and offending; play the victim; and shift all the blame. After hours or days of screaming, during which they fling all their unrelated anger and frustration with their own life, they cry, promise to end this cycle, and then do it again. This, on top of the fact that they don‚Äôt like who I am or care about my happiness, if it deviates from their standards. I never came out of my shell and experienced joy until I left Israel, because I‚Äôd always felt judged and stifled around my family; a delusional freak who ought to be straightened. My entire life, I have let their short temper and destructive defense mechanisms slide. But they will never grow up. The truth is, I lose the will to live every time I return to Israel. Yet I‚Äôm trapped in this dynamic, because I‚Äôm financially dependent on my family. Without intending to, I have come to lead a double life, under a different name, when I‚Äôm far.

  18. If someone had asked me before my birth, ‚ÄúDo you want to come into this world, to this specific time, place, species, and family that you are stuck with?‚Äù I would have said no. This reality is not worth existing.

  19. Then again, misery and lack are the parents of creativity. Without my lifelong letdowns, I would not be who I am.

  20. People can change. They simply don‚Äôt want to.

  21. From high school to the end of my twenties, I felt sixteen. Now, I actually feel like I‚Äôm six. ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt change - they revert,‚Äù a friend told me in autumn. ‚ÄúThey build an armor for themselves in adolescence. Some muster up the courage to shed it in adulthood, and regain their original personality from childhood.‚Äù I am finally who I was before society scarred me: a bold, passionate, lonely, and misunderstood child, who is still learning about the world, leading a messy life, and dreaming of a better future. Except now, I‚Äôm also independent and emotionally capable. My political views have always been left-wing anarchist, and I rebel against any system that oppresses me.

  22. Age is just a number. When I was 19, my best friend was 32; I led the lifestyle of a thirty-something office worker. It was always abundantly clear to me that I would go through the stages of life in reverse. Nowadays, I act like a college graduate.

  23. My entire life has been a search for depth. In the meaning of my existence, the nature of my friendships, and value of my endeavors. In a post-modern digital society ruled by late-stage capitalism, however, five-minute friends, hookups, and memes have turned any earnest pursuit into laughing stock.

  24. Critical thinking is the sole indicator of intellectual intelligence. The ability to step out of your comfort zone and face the unknown is the sole indicator of maturity, which is fed by emotional intelligence. Some people are smart, albeit immature; others are mature, albeit stupid. Many are neither. I look for those who are both.

  25. When I come on terms with one of my flaws, I strive to outgrow it. The next immaturity I should address is my tendency to let people I love walk all over me. Whether friends, certain family members, or lovers - when I turn a blind eye to their red flags, or make excuses for their behavior, I bend over backwards, afraid to lose them. As the only gentle member of my family, I feel bad if I mistreat them the way they mistreat me. So they try to get away with everything around me. Likewise, I tend to idolize a new person I fall in love with, and let them play with me just for a chance to see them again. So I should learn how to love without becoming a doormat.

  26. The universe is as terrifying as it is wondrous. I love it so much, that I hate my love for it. It trapped us on a planet in a cold vacuum with no heartbeat that will expand for eternity. It trapped me in a decaying body, doomed to agonize over my mortality, before turning to dust. I am petrified of demise, whether the universe‚Äôs or mine. I am so scared of dying, that I want to die. And I am alone in the world, but so are we. Aliens are already here - there is no need to send a life signal to outer space. As the Earth warms, humanity turns frigid. Will this bizarre species ever stop prioritizing money over each other? Even my friends and family turn their backs on me. I will forever be an outsider. Humanity is where hope goes to die.

  27. Love is the only cure for time. The only time when time doesn‚Äôt exist. And nothing scares me more than the passage of time. Wrinkles horrify me. Changing digits today makes me want to cry. What will my life look like at forty? Fifty? As a shriveled, failed writer? Who from my present will remain in my future, and what will our habitat look like? I will lose the game of life over and over again, until I won‚Äôt recognize myself in the mirror. In the blink of an eye, everything and everyone that I love will be gone. I am a speck of dust on an ancient, fading mosaic. But I‚Äôd choose terror over despair until my last breath.

  28. I know what it means to love, but not to be loved, and thus, make love. The highlights of my dating life have all enacted the same cycle:- Someone hits on me at least on two different occasions, and suggests meeting.- I am not excited at first, delay our meeting because I‚Äôm busy, but try to keep an open mind.- We meet spontaneously. I fall head over heels. We decide to meet again.- They ghost me. Now I‚Äôm the one chasing them.- Weeks or months pass. I realize I‚Äôm in love. Yet they‚Äôve already disappeared from my life.- More months pass. We talk again briefly. Their lack of interest proves that my feelings are unrequited.This cycle makes me wonder: am I the problem? Making up stories in my head is my favorite thing to do with my consciousness. Maybe I‚Äôm a bit delusional sometimes.

  29. I will never be able to achieve everything I dream of, because my time on this Earth is too brief. There are a thousand things I could have accomplished by now, if it weren‚Äôt for capitalism: novels, short stories, poems, screenplays, movies, songs, albums, travels, paintings, memoirs, and more.Time is money in this world. This limitation led me to stop consuming media two years ago. I barely have time to write my own stories, let alone read or watch other people‚Äôs creations.

  30. Physically, psychologically, socially, and romantically, I am doing better than ever. I might not have a relationship, a publishing deal, readership, someone who cares about my art, and more than one or two real friends, who live on other continents. But I am finally capable of pursuing whatever I want, while forming healthy relationships. I‚Äôve always known who I am and what I want out of life. I‚Äôve always known that I was different from 99% of humans, and wasn‚Äôt meant to come into this world. I‚Äôve always had a plan, and stood behind every big decision I‚Äôve made. It was lack of confidence, caused by my Israeli upbringing, that is to blame for my late blooming. Still, financially, I‚Äôve never been worse. Without intending to, I have become a starving artist. I am not satisfied with most aspects of my existence, and have too many dreams that keep me up at night. Yet I have grown to love myself now, more than ever.

entry.title: Chapter 3: Gotta Shag ‚ÄòEm All!
entry.content:
‚ÄúYou see that buddy over there? I fucked him. See that buddy over there? I fucked him too. I never thought I‚Äôd see them again.‚Äù

Sex and the City (season 1, episode 3)

Everything is the Opposite in Japan

Never underestimate the sexual contents of the homosexual brain. Even when dying of heat and jet lag, studying Japanese at school, and being swamped with relocation errands, it would drift to rainbow-filled pastures from its past.

Kissing Ryder, Ben reminisced in class.

Cuddling Ryder.

Feeling his bare ass.

No amount of homework or difficult words could distract him from bygone pansies, even when surrounded by classmates who struck his fancy.

Sandro‚Äôs sand-coloured hair, ocean eyes, sharp bone structure, and Received Pronunciation made Ben stifle his sighs. Shin‚Äôs short shorts revealed thin, tanned legs. When Ben got paired with the latter, he surprised him by speaking Korean.

Meeting a Korean as delicate as Shin, who had grown up abroad and was fluent in English, was like encountering a unicorn. Yet it was Nathan, a German software engineer, who captured Ben‚Äôs attention the most. His eloquent speech and nerdy passion turned a simple explanation of non-ionizing radiation from cell phones into fascinating lore. Ben stared into Nathan‚Äôs large, blue eyes, and felt right at home.

Still, Nathan worked evenings, and barely had free time. When recess gave the opportunity to mingle, Ben‚Äôs classmates spent it on their desk, glued to their phones.

He grumbled in the hallway. Was it that hard to exchange a few words?

When the teacher asked the students to read a passage out loud, they muttered. Shin spoke so softly, that it sounded like a high-pitched whisper.

Nathan was the only one who talked with enthusiasm and exhibited a sense of humour. The rest seemed serious to the point of being dull. Ben felt silly making jokes in class and reading the written material in a loud voice.

Maybe I should tone myself down.

He struck up a conversation with Zelda about apartments while munching on chocolate and walnut bread. She lived in a new, foreigner-friendly flat in Ebisu three times Ben‚Äôs budget. Her social nicety seemed genuine enough to make him try to befriend her.

In the afternoon, a new real estate agency rejected him off the bat.

‚ÄúForeigners cook smelly curry,‚Äù the agent explained in Japanese. ‚ÄúIt bothers the neighbours.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not Indian,‚Äù Ben said.

‚ÄúThey throw a lot of parties,‚Äù the agent said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a student looking for a small apartment.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt would be hard to convince landlords to trust a foreigner.‚Äù

Ben smiled through his anger. When Nathan had looked for a large apartment with his Japanese ex-girlfriend and begged to pay upfront two years of rent, the landlord had spurned him.

Was this how black people felt in the US? Asians in the West, or Arabs in Israel?

All his life, Ben had been rejected for his individual characteristics, such as personality or appearance. Now, automatic noes were thwarting his efforts, due to an attribute he had no control over. His nature could evolve, but his ethnicity was forever. He‚Äôd never emphasised it in his identity ‚Äì never prided himself over his Ashkenazi Jewish heritage ‚Äì and now, it was foiling him.

This was my grandparents‚Äô past in Europe. And the present of Jews all over the world, ever since the new war.

Everyone at school lived in foreigner-friendly share houses or apartments 45-minutes away. Their location was far and their rent was overpriced, because they had turned to English-speaking realtors.

Refusing to settle on these two conditions, Ben was determined to find a cheap apartment in Shinjuku, where even Japanese people struggled to get their hands on one. Every agent and classmate who heard this desire laughed.

Yet he continued to visit Japanese-only agencies, learning real estate vocabulary instead of words used in class. He had three weeks left in his share house.

Then there were the move-in fees. In Japan, one didn‚Äôt pay just rent: landlords also threw in expenses at the beginning and end of the rental period. Cleaning, lock change, deposit, fire insurance; guarantor, brokerage, and management fees. Worst was key money ‚Äì a present for the landlord. All of this could amount to six months‚Äô rent. To make matters worse, only foreigner-friendly agencies offered one-year contracts.

A mouse was squeaking as Ben hung his laundry. He hated Tokyo at that moment. Money talked all over the world, but here, values took precedence. Respect was thankfully the foremost ideal ‚Äì until a tenant wished to pay for a vacant apartment, but couldn‚Äôt even meet the landlord and prove that he wasn‚Äôt a delinquent.

Today was thirty-seven degrees and seventy-five percent humidity. A flash storm was rumbling every evening lately. Constant sweat didn‚Äôt exactly facilitate Ben‚Äôs psoriasis. Weather, errands, and classwork would leave him no time to go back to dating ‚Äì and this was just his second week here.

*

The next day, he met the real-life, Japanese version of The Incredibles‚Äô Edna Mode: his new favourite teacher. They wrote essays for the first time; Ben and Nathan checked each other‚Äôs.

Mr Perfect‚Äôs obsidian eyes, the former pictured in his head. Mr Perfect‚Äôs long, chiselled figure.

Nathan struggled to understand much of Ben‚Äôs kanji and grammar. His essay was rife with errors and unnatural phrases. But when he explained cosmic radiation to Ben during recess, none of this mattered.

Next year, he would return to Germany. Ben swallowed his disappointment.

Shin would leave after this term as well. Who among my classmates would become my friend, considering our limited time together?

After school, the staff introduced him to the other Israeli students. Two guys and three girls from the other levels. They seemed nice, until one rose above the rest.

Oksana was a Ukrainian-born goth with a slow, Russian accent. No sooner had Ben sat with her in the common area, than an hour flew by.

‚ÄúI had the same experience when I came here, and it hasn‚Äôt gotten any better,‚Äù she said regarding the anti-social vibe of Ben‚Äôs level five class. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs opened up yet.‚Äù

This was coming from a level two student. Several beginner students hung out in the common area every day, did homework, and ate lunch. Those in the upper levels, however, were already too ingrained in their routine to expand their circle. Moreover, they already knew each other.

‚ÄúAre people really content spending a year just studying and working?‚Äù Ben complained.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so sad,‚Äù Oksana said.

He wondered if his classmates simply dismissed his company, the way ex-lovers had.

Mr Perfect‚Äôs weird, Eastern European accent.

When Ben caught sight of Oksana‚Äôs bunny trinkets and mentioned visiting a rabbit shrine in Kyoto, goosebumps spread all over her arms.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt understand, I love bunnies,‚Äù she trembled in excitement.

The school staff helped Ben with a new, potential apartment. Its prime location and mint condition didn‚Äôt match the suspiciously low rent. The staff checked the listing on a Japanese website, which showed if a tragedy had struck certain buildings. Fire, suicide, murder. Nothing whatsoever.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd better go see it ASAP,‚Äù the staff said.

Ben ran to the property. The agency‚Äôs day off meant that he‚Äôd enter by himself. The realtor instructed him how to unlock the mailbox containing the key, yet no amount of rotating the dial did the trick. It took him ten minutes to realize that the realtor‚Äôs left was his right.

Everything was the opposite in Japan.

The apartment was superb, apart from a balcony overlooking the street. Passersby could see right in.

Disappointed, Ben rushed to Kabukicho for his flatmate‚Äôs wrestling match.

Japanese girls in lingerie hosted the ‚Äòshow‚Äô. In a country whose female population dressed like puritans, this was quite the shock. The wrestlers pretended to fight, writhe in pain, and spank each other.

‚ÄúPlease be careful!‚Äù the announcer repeated as the crowd cheered. ‚ÄúDo your best!‚Äù

The male wrestlers stripped to their underwear.

Ryder‚Äôs maid costume.

A large penis.

After the match, Ben‚Äôs flatmates escorted him back to the apartment. Despite the central location, its street was quiet.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not taking it,‚Äù the wrestler said in disbelief, ‚ÄúI am.‚Äù

The realtor was pressuring him to seal the deal. But it was out of budget.

‚ÄúThis is what I paid per month,‚Äù Nathan said regarding the apartment‚Äôs move-in fees.

‚ÄúWell, we have different professions,‚Äù Ben said. ‚ÄúYou have one, and I don‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúRegardless of order, I believe that every relationship must endure two tests,‚Äù Nathan said. ‚ÄúA big change, and a big fight.‚Äù

With Ryder, Ben had survived neither.

Nathan pointed out how, when Japanese couples broke up, they returned to the dating scene the next day, as if nothing had transpired.

‚ÄúYou become a couple so fast,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúthat it carries less weight.‚Äù

In the Western world, people tested the waters across all three bases before hitting home run. A break-up actually broke your heart.

Ben looked down at his plate. His heart had been broken even without an official break-up. A relationship wasn‚Äôt a stage he‚Äôd reached, despite two months of dating, living together, and discussing weddings.

*

He spent the weekend in bed, writing for hours without getting up for food or a drink.

Missionary.

Cowboy.

Reverse cowboy.

Ryder‚Äôs incredulous moan.

His heart skipped a beat upon publishing the first chapter of this story. Months of preparation had led to this. Yet by the end of the day, none of his friends acknowledged it.

Sex and the City had premiered as a dark dramedy about the death of love. After viewership had risen, it had concluded as a fairy tale rom-com. But throughout its run, one detail had remained realistic: Carrie Bradshaw‚Äôs closest friends never read, let alone brought up, her columns.

Neither did Ben‚Äôs friends and family. After years of daily writing, pain from romantic defeats, and life-changing growth, nothing had made him prouder than crafting this new story.

He felt betrayed by every person in his life.

‚ÄúStop being such a baby,‚Äù he imagined Ha-joon saying. ‚ÄúPeople do what they want.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt expect anything out of anyone,‚Äù Will would have said, if they were here.

He continued apartment hunting instead. Two weeks of daily searches had yielded several good options, which rejected him automatically.

In the evening, Ben‚Äôs first visit to the grocery store raised his spirits.

In Japan, supermarkets opened with a takeout section. Sushi, salads, grilled fish, noodles. Half off around dinner time.

Then there was fresh produce, packed and presented like in a hotel. Fruit and vegetables native to both the East and West. But the cherry on top were mini melons and square watermelons.

The fish section was a hunter-gatherer‚Äôs heaven. Fresh, clean, and cheap.

Finally, bagging stations prevented customers from holding up the queue at the cash register.

After indulging on daifuku and sashimi, Ben went to bed at three AM.

Doggy.

On the floor.

Against the wall.

Head buried in ass.

He woke too sick to leave bed or eat anything. He hated how his dreams depended on other people.

The following day, a middle-aged fisherman he‚Äôd met in Onomichi visited Tokyo, and offered to accompany Ben to a new real estate agency. The realtor showed them an apartment in Shinjuku that ticked off all his boxes: location, budget, and condition.

Mr Perfect‚Äôs tender whispers.

Perhaps it was the presence of a Japanese companion. Perhaps this agency had a different pool of properties. Whatever it was, Ben said yes on the spot.

‚ÄúI felt it was time to call it a night. I had never felt so invisible in my entire life.‚Äù

Sex and the City (season 1, episode 2)

First Day of School

Everywhere a homo went, there was only one question in his head.

Any cute boys?

First day of school, he would scour the class.

First day of work, he would scour the office.

First day of volunteering, he would scour the guesthouse.

Every outing to a bar was like a secret service agent scouting for a target. Or a dog sniffing for drugs.

Yet starting today, all Ben could get high off was pen and paper. He was a student again.

He slept three hours and rushed to his new school with bloodshot eyes. The Starbucks cup from 7-11 in his hand was like a chef with takeaway. Yet desperate times called for desperate measures.

Surveying sixty new students during orientation proved exciting enough to rouse Ben. Most were tall, white guys.

‚ÄúDoes anyone intend to buy a bicycle?‚Äù the principal asked. ‚ÄúEvery bicycle in Japan needs to be registered, and it‚Äôs hard to find parking. Even slight offences, such as driving tickets, can ruin all your future visa applications. So please let us know in advance.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou also need the school‚Äôs approval every time you leave the country,‚Äù another staffer said.

Ben smiled. Back to academic rules and complaining about homework. Back to going out with international friends and stressing over exams.

For the first time in his life, he would live in a big city: the biggest on Earth.

It occurred to him that he was not nervous at all. Meeting a plethora of new people, relocating to a new country, being on his own. Only two threats made his chest constrict nowadays. Love and finance.

‚ÄúI love Japan, but the people are so polite, that it becomes fake,‚Äù a new French student voiced Ben‚Äôs thoughts from last night at a conveyor belt sushi in Kabukicho. ‚ÄúI want to find real friends who are honest.‚Äù

A blue-eyed ginger with a baseball cap who towered over the locals, his Japanese girlfriend had recently gotten pregnant.

‚ÄúA foreigner who‚Äôd been living here for forty years had once told me that I would never become Japanese,‚Äù Ben said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs okay. I don‚Äôt want to. I want to be a foreigner who lives in Japan.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, the people in Tokyo, they look so lifeless,‚Äù the French said. ‚ÄúThey go to the office, scroll on their phone inside a train, work all day, and return home.‚Äù

Yet in true Tokyo fashion, Ben declined the offer to continue the conversation at an izakaya over drinks. He nearly fell asleep at the restaurant.

*

There were two hundred students in Ben‚Äôs Japanese language school in Shin Okubo, and eleven in his class. They hailed from Germany, Italy, France, Ukraine, Switzerland, South Korea, Taiwan, and the US.

What was he doing here? Ben freaked out the moment he sat down.

The Korean looked like someone he had dated in Busan. Short and skinny, with monolid eyes, oversized nineties streetwear, and a baseball cap. This was the rare Korean twink, bashful and soft-spoken, who seemed more Japanese.

An anchovy, Ben imagined Ha-joon saying.

Shin introduced himself in a voice that was barely audible. Ben immediately resolved to befriend him.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù the teacher, a middle-aged Japanese woman, said after the introductions. ‚ÄúHow does everyone study kanji?‚Äù

The students all blinked downward.

‚ÄúI pray at a temple,‚Äù Ben joked in Japanese.

‚ÄúEh?‚Äù the teacher chuckled in confusion.

The students glanced at Ben without laughing. He wanted to drop out.

Recess brought better interactions. Kacie was a quiet girl from Taichung who marvelled at Ben‚Äôs exploits in Taiwan. Kristen was an American graphic designer who worked with Japanese rock bands, and attended their concerts weekly. Zelda radiated a high-fashion cross between elf and fairy. Aubrey seemed like the anime-inspired little sister of Billie Eilish, with silver pins on her scarlet hair, a doll-like face, and camouflage cargo pants.

Sandro was a handsome Italian with a pointed bone structure that accentuated his ocean eyes and sandy hair. Tall and athletic, he spoke eloquently with received pronunciation from a London relocation.

Yet it was Nathan, a German software engineer, who made frequent conversations with Ben. He was easy and engrossing to talk to, like an affable bust of a young Roman emperor come to life.

With thick, wavy hair escaping his cap, a trimmed beard, fair skin, and subtle features, Ben found himself staring at Nathan‚Äôs electric blue eyes. He recalled predicting on the first day of his two degrees who his friends would be. Back then, he was too shy to initiate any hangouts after class. Yet now, when he waited for Nathan in the afternoon and noticed how every student went to their own way, he returned to his share house disappointed.

He was the only student who had enrolled straight into an advanced class. By level five out of eight, everyone had been studying at this school for at least six months.

They already knew each other, he sighed_. But didn‚Äôt they want to at least grab lunch?_

‚ÄúThe guys all have Japanese girlfriends, too,‚Äù he complained to Mayume on the phone.

‚ÄúStraggots,‚Äù Mayume muttered. ‚ÄúBland chicken is at the top of the food pyramid in Asia.‚Äù

‚ÄúSeriously though, those white-guy, Asian-girl couples are literally everywhere,‚Äù Ben said. ‚ÄúBut never the opposite.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe should follow their example,‚Äù Mayume said.

‚ÄúIn your dreams,‚Äù Ben hung up.

He crashed on his bed and browsed rental apartments online with zombie eyes. Mayume, Ha-joon, and Will went out to ni-chome at night. But Ben was too tired and busy to join them. All he could do was recall the past.

Tokyo Pride in Ni-Chome

Saturday night at the most popular gay club in Japan, on the eve of Pride.

Muscle shirts, alcohol, pop music, and go-go boys. The music was loud, the people were countless, and the kissing was omnipresent.

I walked for five minutes from my hotel to Shinjuku ni-chome, Tokyo‚Äôs queer paradise. A rainbow torii graced the entrance of a famous bar. It was so crowded, that most of the patrons were drinking outside.

Then I stood in line to the club: my first one. I was nervous, but this trip was about trying new things.

Inside was more teeming than a bakery with free buns. I got sake and squeezed my way to the dance floor.

It felt weird. I never danced. A few people were standing in the back with their drinks in hand, looking uncomfortable. I forced myself to not join them.

So I started to move my body. I mimicked other dancers, and slowly let loose. The floor-to-ceiling mirrors almost made me cringe.

It didn‚Äôt help that there was a couple next to me on a mission to break the world record for longest smooch in history. They sucked each other‚Äôs faces like oxygen masks in vacuum.

I grew hot. The cramped bodies engulfing me reeked. Disco balls dazzled while neon spotlights pranced around the dim party. It appeared as though I was the only lone wolf.

A Japanese guy took me aside, handed me a wireless earphone, and put on Nicki Minaj. We listened to her rapping as ABBA proclaimed everyone ‚Äòdancing queens‚Äô.

I returned to my spot in the middle of the floor, hungry for a better encounter. Beefy go-go boys were dancing on the screens. Three muscular Asians with perky bangs and tank tops were making good use of their tongues in a three-way kiss.

Then a skinny guy with bubble-gum pink bangs and oversized clothes danced with me. He kept trying to touch me, yet I wasn‚Äôt feeling it.

The tallest guy in the club walked in. He wore black designer streetwear and heaps of silver jewelry, like an Asian fashion model from Berlin.

Everyone seemed to know him, or want to know him. He greeted partygoers with a gracious smile, accompanied by a guy that reminded me of Middle Easterners from back home.

The pink twink had moved on to other candidates, pecking them one after the other.

After some time, the Asian-German started dancing shirtless. Like an underwear model, he had a six pack and perfect skin.

Bodies were bumping against each other, making shots of alcohol spill. Sweat and musk were filling the air. The model‚Äôs face beamed brighter than the disco lights. The entire scene didn‚Äôt seem real.

Suddenly, I felt d√©j√† vu. This packed nightclub made me feel ecstatic and wretched, just like a recent temple stay in Koya-san.

I enjoyed dancing and partaking in a liberated, queer atmosphere ‚Äì yet felt like rotten meat. The same dejection darkened the pink twink‚Äôs face. He was ogling the crowd in a defeated pout, after his hunt had failed.

So I closed my eyes. Enough worrying about my appearance. Enough fretting over all the couples kissing.

Not knowing who was around me, how appetizing and better at dancing they seemed, and whether they were watching me, warmed my cold feet. I whirled my body. I danced. I focused on my physicality and the music blaring in my ears, the lyrics I was yelling, and the songs that uplifted me.

I let the sea of people push me, move me, relocate me, without seeing where my shoes landed. Nothing mattered at this moment: the spot I inhabited, the swaying of my hips, or my invisibility next to all the Asian Adonis. I felt d√©j√† vu again, this time to Shodoshima, where I‚Äôd cycled up a deserted mountain a week after Koya-san, gazed at a foggy port beneath me, and screamed with bliss.

I felt free.

A nightclub was the last place I‚Äôd expected to elicit that. I‚Äôd always lied in order to skip parties and stay in my room.

Now, I cracked a smile. I stopped craving the gourmet meals around me, I quit revolting at my insipidity, and instead grinned, and chuckled, and laughed.

Was this me? Was it really happening?

Yes, I was, it was ‚Äì and I found myself in seventh heaven.

As singers continued to roar and dancers to shove me, a pair of arms touched my torso.

I opened my eyes. A Japanese guy was holding my waist, chortling as if snorting laughing gas.

‚ÄúWait a second!‚Äù he yelled in Japanese, when I followed his lead and danced with him. He could barely stand from all the laughter.

I must have embarrassed myself. He excused himself and left. Disappointed, I danced with my mouth wide and eyes shut.

That was when another set of arms embraced me.

They belonged to a white guy with a skirt, emo bangs, and cat ears. We danced together, until I found myself challenging the world-record couple.

Then he led me outside.

My first breath of fresh air in four hours. My ears were ringing. I felt like I‚Äôd suffered permanent hearing damage.

We found a quiet, external staircase. I learned that he was a British student of video game music, who also preferred Japan to his country of origin.

‚ÄúAre you high?‚Äù he asked. My uninhibited dancing had given him this impression.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI had one sake. This is actually my first time clubbing.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is?‚Äù

I explained my lifelong avoidance of clubs, and tonight‚Äôs inconceivable fun.

‚ÄúSo you were high on life,‚Äù he said. A phrase I‚Äôd never heard.

‚ÄúI want to use it as a title for my next post,‚Äù I said, transfixed. By now, he‚Äôd learned about my blog.

‚ÄúNo, that‚Äôs so clich√©.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrue. I probably embarrassed myself way too much already.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, that was kind of embarrassing,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs why I approached you.‚Äù

The more we talked, the more we found out how much we had in common. Certain beloved anime, or running a website dedicated to our passions. Dreaming of a career in arts. He had also given himself an unorthodox nickname. Every revelation like this made way for disbelief and laughter. Lots and lots of laughter.

Shivering on a building‚Äôs staircase at witching hour, we marvelled at our shared interests, to the point where it felt exhilarating.

He was six years younger than me. Yet he was already explaining the lore of ni-chome, where he‚Äôd seen men do a lot more than exchange fluids in the alleys.

His sapphire eyes mesmerized me. His articulate voice, I could listen to for hours. A British accent that had become American, for the locals‚Äô comprehension.

Who was this person? Was this really happening?

I fell asleep with him in my bed at 4:00, no longer a rubbish bag in a patisserie of delicacies.

Gym Twins or Gay Couple?

Sunset outside the Museum of Modern Art, Tokyo. Ben waited until Mayume arrived late in sweaty sportswear.

‚ÄúWhy do you run every night?‚Äù Ben asked. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre already skinny.‚Äù

Mayume was panting heavily. A Japanese twunk in short shorts jogged past them.

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou could‚Äôve replied that you were running late,‚Äù Ben said, trying to focus on Mayume instead. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre so bad at texting.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou realize this just now?‚Äù Mayume asked.

‚ÄúNo, it was clear from like a week after we met.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood, then it‚Äôs a reminder.‚Äù Mayume chugged from a bottle of water bigger than him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to Mongolia. Can‚Äôt bear this scorching weather.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor vacation?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll come back after a month,‚Äù he said, spelling ‚Äòc-u-m‚Äô out loud. ‚ÄúJuly 31 to be exact.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care,‚Äù Ben said. ‚ÄúHave fun milking goats on the mountains.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou never cared from the beginning.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrue.‚Äù

They smiled at each other. Smooth legs were running wild in short shorts, as if a road lined with skyscrapers and a river was their natural habitat, more than any park in Tokyo.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine with it,‚Äù Mayume said, beginning to walk.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre dead on the inside.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow about the outside?‚Äù
